title: Light, flexible and radiation-resistant: Organic solar cells for space - University of Michigan News
summary:
Light, flexible and radiation-resistant: Organic solar cells for space

Publication Date: Not specified Source: University of Michigan

The University of Michigan’s latest study suggests that organic solar cells, made from carbon-based materials, could outperform traditional silicon and gallium arsenide cells in space. These organic cells show resilience against radiation, making them suitable for space missions.

  • Organic materials demonstrate no degradation after three years of radiation exposure.
  • Silicon semiconductors suffer performance drops due to proton irradiation.
  • Proton radiation can create electron traps that degrade solar cell efficiency.
  • Organic solar cells are lighter and more flexible than their silicon counterparts.
  • Thermal annealing may help repair radiation damage, but further research is needed to understand self-healing in space.
“Silicon semiconductors aren’t stable in space because of proton irradiation coming from the sun.” - Yongxi Li

The findings represent a significant advancement in solar technology for extraterrestrial use, encouraging further exploration into the reliability and application of organic solar cells in future space missions.
newTitle: Organic Solar Cells Show Promise for Space Applications

title: NASA Solar Dynamics Observatory back online after 2024 data center flood - Space.com
summary:
NASA Solar Dynamics Observatory back online after 2024 data center flood

Publication Date: January 8, 2025

Source: Space.com

More than a month after a flooded data center at Stanford University knocked out data processing operations for two NASA sun-studying spacecraft, solar scientists are starting to regain access to information and images beamed to Earth by the instruments.

A restored database server is 'functioning adequately' with back-up servers ready for use, and data processing has begun from the time of the flooding incident going forward.

  • The flooding incident on November 26 damaged roughly 20% of the computer systems.
  • The Helioseismic and Magnetic Imager (HMI) and Atmospheric Imaging Array (AIA) archives became inaccessible.
  • The first stage of the processing pipeline for incoming data was restarted by December 20, but with reduced capacity.
  • Despite the outage, the spacecraft continued to operate normally, meaning no science data was lost.
"Restoration of the database servers that manage the storage of the billions of files in the JSOC repository is our first and foremost challenge — this is our highest priority."

The team is awaiting replacement parts for other damaged data servers, which are expected to arrive soon, to assess recoverable data.
newTitle: NASA Solar Dynamics Observatory back online after 2024 data center flood

title: World's darkest and clearest skies at risk from industrial megaproject - Phys.org
summary:
World's Darkest and Clearest Skies Under Threat from Industrial Project

Date: January 10, 2025 | Source: ESO

This article discusses the significant threat posed by a proposed industrial megaproject near the ESO's Paranal Observatory in Chile, which could lead to light pollution and harm astronomical observations.

  • The project, submitted by AES Andes, is planned just 5 to 11 kilometers from the observatory.
  • Paranal Observatory is renowned for its clear skies, crucial for astronomical research.
  • Notable scientific achievements include the first image of an exoplanet and contributions to understanding the universe's expansion.
  • The project would cover over 3000 hectares and poses risks of dust and light pollution.
  • Experts urge the relocation of the project to preserve the unique dark skies essential for astronomy.
"Chile, and in particular Paranal, is a truly special place for astronomy—its dark skies are a natural heritage that transcends its borders and benefits all humanity." - Itziar de Gregorio, ESO's Representative in Chile

The potential industrial development endangers not just local astronomy but the global scientific community’s ability to observe the universe effectively, urging the need for responsible site selection to protect this vital resource.
newTitle: World's Darkest and Clearest Skies Under Threat from Industrial Project

Cumbre Vieja study suggests that magma composition drives volcanic tremor - Phys.org
summary:
Cumbre Vieja study suggests that magma composition drives volcanic tremor

Publication Date: January 10, 2025 | Source: Phys.org

A recent study indicates that the composition of magma may influence volcanic tremors during eruptions at the Cumbre Vieja volcano in the Canary Islands. Conducted by researchers from the American Museum of Natural History and City University of New York, the study emphasizes the utility of volcanic ash analysis as a forecasting tool.

  • The study details how silica levels in magma relate to the volcano's tremor intensity.
  • Gathered samples captured 94% of the eruption timeline, allowing for unprecedented chemical analysis.
  • The findings could improve eruption forecasting and hazard assessment measures globally.
  • Coordination challenges during eruptions must be overcome for effective petrological monitoring.
“If our findings hold true for other volcanoes, we might be able to monitor interior magma properties from the surface of an eruption...” - Samantha Tramontano

This research bridges the gap between chemical data and physical eruption characteristics, providing new insights into volcanic activity.
newTitle: Cumbre Vieja Study Highlights Link Between Magma Composition and Volcanic Tremors

See the moon and Jupiter ride the Bull in tonight’s sky - Space.com
summary:
See the moon and Jupiter ride the Bull in tonight’s sky

Date: January 10, 2025
Source: Space.com

The moon will pass closely by Jupiter this evening, meeting up with the gas giant in the constellation Taurus.

Both celestial bodies will be visible shortly after sunset.

  • The closest approach occurs at 4:45 p.m. EST.
  • They will be highest in the sky at 9:14 p.m. EST.
  • The moon is currently in a waxing gibbous phase, 92% illuminated.
  • Jupiter will appear bright in comparison, with a magnitude of -2.7.
“During their close approach, the pair will enter a celestial arrangement known as a conjunction.”

Don’t miss the chance to observe this beautiful astronomical event.
newTitle: See the moon and Jupiter ride the Bull in tonight’s sky

title: Why Donald Trump Will Decide How Mars Soil Samples Reach Earth | Explained - News18
summary:
Why Donald Trump Will Decide How Mars Soil Samples Reach Earth

Date: January 11, 2025

Source: News18

NASA's Perseverance Rover has collected numerous soil samples on Mars, but details regarding their return to Earth are limited. The process involves a two-phase approach, where decisions will ultimately be made by then-US President Donald Trump.

  • The Mars Sample Return Program will likely have two phases: sample retrieval and transportation.
  • Key cost and time factors will be influenced by the chosen method, which relies on technology differences.
  • NASA has received 11 studies on possible methods for sample transport from the Mars Sample Return Strategic Review Team.
  • The decision-making will rest with President Trump in late 2026, amidst budgets and political considerations.
NASA aims to significantly reduce the program's cost and duration while unlocking secrets about Mars and the universe.

In conclusion, this event will shape the future exploration of Mars and may unlock crucial scientific understanding, but the timing and method remain uncertain.
newTitle: Why Donald Trump Will Decide How Mars Soil Samples Reach Earth

title: 6 Very Beautiful Images Of Moon Taken By NASA - Times Now
summary:
6 Very Beautiful Images Of Moon Taken By NASA

Publication Date: January 10, 2025, Source: Times Now

This article showcases six breathtaking images of the Moon captured by NASA, highlighting the beauty and intrigue of Earth's natural satellite.

  • 2017 Total Solar Eclipse image showing the Sun's corona.
  • Full Moon photo taken from the International Space Station.
  • Unique perspective of the Moon by NASA's MESSENGER spacecraft.
  • Tycho Crater captured by the Hubble Space Telescope.
  • Oblique view of the Copernicus crater taken by Lunar Orbiter 2.
  • Image of the Moon captured by NASA’s Galileo spacecraft in 1992.
“These images aid in understanding the physics and structure of the Moon, showcasing its beauty and our capabilities of capturing it from various spaces.”

This collection of images not only emphasizes the aesthetic appeal of the Moon but also engages audiences in lunar exploration and science.
newTitle: Stunning NASA Images of the Moon

title: Jupiter’s Clouds: A Breakthrough Discovery by Combining Old and New Techniques - PUNE.NEWS
summary:
Amateur Astronomer Challenges Long-Held Assumptions About Jupiter’s Clouds

Publication Date: N/A
Source: PUNE.NEWS

An amateur astronomer has provided a new perspective on Jupiter's atmospheric composition, leading to significant revelations that challenge established beliefs regarding the planet's iconic clouds.

This groundbreaking discovery utilized old techniques merging with modern tools, demonstrating the power of collaboration between amateur and professional astronomers.

  • Steve Hill used band-depth analysis to study Jupiter's clouds and found limited ammonia ice presence.
  • Collaboration with Dr. Patrick Irwin and data from advanced instruments validated Hill's findings.
  • Breakthroughs suggest clouds contain ammonium hydrosulfide or photochemical smog instead of primarily ammonia ice.
“Even seemingly simple observations can push the boundaries of our understanding.” - Dr. Irwin

The implications of this research extend to Saturn as well, suggesting similar cloud composition due to analogous photochemical processes. Future research is necessary to refine these findings and deepen our understanding of gas giants.
newTitle: Amateur Astronomer Challenges Assumptions About Jupiter’s Clouds

How does Earth look from space? 7 pics that show our planet's beauty from above

  • The images reveal the stunning oceans, weather patterns, and light from cities at night.

  • The gallery offers a humbling perspective on our planet’s beauty and fragility.
“Viewing Earth from space offers a humbling perspective of our planet’s beauty and fragility.”

These striking visuals serve as a reminder of the connectivity and wonder of our world, encouraging appreciation for Earth's natural landscapes.

Stargazers in Hong Kong to witness rare alignment of 4 planets - South China Morning Post
summary:
Stargazers in Hong Kong to Witness Rare Alignment of 4 Planets

Publication Date: February 2023 Source: Local News

Hong Kong residents will have the rare opportunity to observe four of the brightest planets in the solar system with the naked eye until the end of February. The city's space museum will host a live stream of the astronomical event on Friday.

  • The phenomenon is known as a planetary parade, where several planets are visible in the night sky simultaneously.
  • This parade will predominantly feature Venus, Saturn, Jupiter, and Mars.
  • By the end of February, the public will be able to see six planets, including Neptune and Uranus, but the latter two will require telescopes.
  • Currently, alignments with four or more visible planets occur once every few years.
“Residents can just observe [the planets] with the naked eye,” said Kenneth Chiu Kam-hung, assistant curator at the Hong Kong Space Museum.

The live stream of the planetary alignment will take place on Friday from 7.30pm to 8.30pm.
newTitle: Stargazers in Hong Kong to Witness Rare Alignment of 4 Planets

In Photos: Jaw-Dropping Jupiter And Its Moon Io As Seen By NASA’s Juno - Forbes
summary:
In Photos: Jaw-Dropping Jupiter And Its Moon Io As Seen By NASA’s Juno

Publication Date: December 28, 2024

Source: Forbes

Nasa's Juno spacecraft has sent back stunning images of Jupiter and its moon Io, revealing details about their dynamic atmospheres and volcanic activity.

  • The Juno spacecraft captured images of Jupiter during its 68th close flyby.
  • Citizen scientists processed the images to highlight Jupiter's swirling storms and Io's volcanic surface.
  • Juno detected heat rising from Io’s subsurface, highlighting its intense volcanic activity.
  • Juno’s mission has expanded scientists' understanding of both Jupiter and its moons.
  • The mission is nearing its conclusion with a planned dive into Jupiter's atmosphere in September 2025.
“Juno has defied expectations, surviving Jupiter’s harsh radiation and extreme conditions.”

The captured images provide insight into Jupiter’s atmosphere and Io's geology, deepening our understanding of these celestial bodies.
newTitle: Jaw-Dropping Images of Jupiter and Io Captured by NASA’s Juno

title: ESA spacecraft captures images of Mercury’s surface during flyby - Madhyamam
Research discovers new skeletal tissue with potential for regeneration: Study - The Tribune India
summary:
Research Discovers New Skeletal Tissue with Potential for Regeneration

Publication Date: December 10, 2023 Source: The Tribune

An international research team has uncovered a new type of skeletal tissue, known as lipocartilage, which may revolutionize regenerative medicine and tissue engineering.

  • The study, led by the University of California, Irvine, identifies lipocartilage found in mammals' ears, nose, and throat, demonstrating unique structural properties.
  • Unlike traditional cartilage, lipocartilage is made up of fat-filled cells called lipochondrocytes, providing stability and elasticity.
  • The research, published in the journal Science, reveals that lipochondrocytes maintain consistent sizes and can create lipid reservoirs without shrinking in response to food availability.
  • Potential applications include creating patient-specific cartilage from stem cells, which could be 3D printed to treat facial defects and various cartilage diseases.
  • Findings also include the understanding of genetic processes that regulate fat storage within the cartilage.
“Lipocartilage's resilience and stability provide a compliant, elastic quality that's perfect for flexible body parts such as earlobes or the tip of the nose,” said Maksim Plikus, the study's corresponding author.

This discovery opens new avenues for less invasive cartilage reconstruction techniques, promising a future where patients can receive personalized medical solutions for tissue repair.
newTitle: Research Discovers New Skeletal Tissue with Potential for Regeneration

title: Research discovers new skeletal tissue with potential for regeneration: Study - ANI News
Single-Step Flame-Retardant Coating Could Save Lives and Property - Technology Networks
summary:
Single-Step Flame-Retardant Coating Could Save Lives and Property

Publication Date: 2024

Source: Texas A&M University

Researchers from Texas A&M University have developed a new flame-retardant coating for cotton that can be applied in a single step, which may help save lives and property.

  • The coating uses a polyelectrolyte complex that reduces the flammability of cotton.
  • This technology can be tailored for various textiles and is suitable for industrial applications.
  • Current methods require multiple steps, increasing costs and time.
  • The new approach uses ammonia as a volatile base to induce chemical reactions on cotton.
  • The technology is non-toxic and environmentally friendly.
  • Continued research may lead to applications in wood, fabric, foam, and more.
“This cutting-edge research offers Texas A&M recognition as one of the leaders of this technology and the opportunity for further development with external companies,” said Dr. Jaime Grunlan.

This flame-retardant coating technology represents a significant advancement in enhancing everyday safety through innovative materials science.
newTitle: Single-Step Flame-Retardant Coating Could Save Lives and Property

title: Asymmetric Graphene Ribbon Breakthrough Could Advance Quantum Tech - Technology Networks
summary:
Asymmetric Graphene Ribbon Breakthrough Could Advance Quantum Tech

Publication Date: 9 January 2025 Source: Nature

Researchers from the National University of Singapore have achieved a significant breakthrough in carbon-based quantum materials, particularly in the development of Janus graphene nanoribbons (JGNR), which could advance quantum electronics.

  • The JGNR features a unique zigzag edge with a ferromagnetic edge state.
  • This design enables the creation of one-dimensional ferromagnetic spin chains for quantum applications.
  • The research involved international collaboration among chemists, materials scientists, and physicists.
  • Assoc Prof Lu Jiong highlighted the potential of JGNR for quantum technologies due to long spin coherence times.
  • The findings were published in the scientific journal Nature.
Assoc Prof Lu said, “Magnetic graphene nanoribbons... offers tremendous potential for quantum technologies due to their long spin coherence times and the potential to operate at room temperature.”

This breakthrough opens new avenues for precise engineering of quantum materials and the development of next-generation quantum computing technologies.
newTitle: Asymmetric Graphene Ribbon Breakthrough Could Advance Quantum Tech

summary:
7 Mind-Blowing Galaxy Images Captured by NASA

NASA has shared multiple stunning images of galaxies that showcase the beauty and complexity of the universe. Each image highlights different features and phenomena associated with various galaxies.

  • Featured images include stunning captures from the Spitzer Space Telescope and Hubble Telescope.
  • The spiral arms of the nearby galaxy Messier 81 are remarkably showcased.
  • The immense Andromeda galaxy is presented in spectacular detail.
  • Nasa’s Spitzer Telescope revealed the Milky Way’s hidden center.
  • New insights on the magnetic fields of Centaurus A from the SOFIA telescope.
  • A unique X-ray view of the Milky Way's center reveals superheated gas threads.
  • NASA’s Fermi Gamma-ray Space Telescope captured twin bubbles extending from the galactic center.
  • A recent Hubble image of NGC 6951, a spiral galaxy 78 million light-years away was shared.

“NASA’s Spitzer Telescope reveals the Milky Way’s hidden center, showing its dense, star-packed core.”

This collection of images not only showcases NASA's technological advancements in space observation but also offers a glimpse into the vastness and mystery of our universe.
newTitle: 7 Mind-Blowing Galaxy Images Captured by NASA

title: Stem Cell Study Points to the Evolutionary Origins of the Outer Ear - Technology Networks
summary:
Stem Cell Study Points to the Evolutionary Origins of the Outer Ear

Publication Date: N/A | Source: Technology Networks

The outer ear, unique to mammals, has mysterious evolutionary origins. A new study suggests it may have evolved from the ancient gills of fish and marine invertebrates.

  • The study was conducted by Gage Crump's USC Stem Cell lab and published in Nature.
  • Researchers discovered both gills and outer ears are composed of elastic cartilage.
  • Gene control elements called enhancers linked the development of gills and outer ears in transgenic zebrafish and mice.
  • The study tracks the evolutionary path from gills to the prominent outer ears of early mammals.
  • Findings suggest elastic cartilage could have originated in ancient marine invertebrates over 400 million years ago.
“This work provides a new chapter to the evolution of the mammalian ear,” said Crump.

This research highlights the evolutionary adaptations of mammalian ears and opens new avenues for understanding developmental biology.
newTitle: Stem Cell Study Reveals Origins of the Outer Ear

title: 300 million-year-old hotspot linked to the formation of the Great Lakes discovered by scientists; where i - The Times of India
summary:
300 million-year-old hotspot linked to the formation of the Great Lakes discovered by scientists; where is it now?

Publication Date: N/A

Source: N/A

The discovery of a hotspot beneath the ancient supercontinent Pangaea is a significant advancement in understanding the geological history of the Great Lakes region.

  • The Cape Verde hotspot has been linked to the formation of the Great Lakes over 300 million years ago.
  • The discovery reveals how tectonic activities and glacial movements contributed to shaping the landscape.
  • Seismic anomalies indicate past deformation of the lithosphere beneath the Great Lakes region influenced by the hotspot.
“The connection between the Cape Verde hotspot and the Great Lakes adds a new layer of understanding to geological processes.”

This groundbreaking research helps to understand not just the formation of the Great Lakes, but also the broader trends in geological developments influenced by ancient hotspots.
newTitle: 300 Million-Year-Old Hotspot Linked to Formation of Great Lakes Discovered
